text: hi everyone Anthony fantano here the
internet's busiest music nerd and it's
time for a review of the new wild beasts
album present tense these guys are a UK
based art pie outfit and this is their
fourth full-length album
a band that's known for its Whimsical
songwriting and Incredibly theatrical
and dramatic singing from Dual front men
Tom Fleming and Hayden Thorpe the
singing on their LPS really is wild
BEAST's most defining characteristic
however across many of their records the
most persistent issue for me has just
really been the sound of their
instrumentation the sound of their music
in general I think the Achilles heel of
the band's last LP smother was that the
instrumentation sounded so plain on that
record while the vocals and tunes are
fantastic and really sharp a lot of the
time I find the guitars and the drums
and occasionally synths to be just a
little too dry a little colorless a
little lifeless however it is their
sound that the band is overhauling on
this newest LP of theirs as I heard in
an interview I did with frontman Hayden
Thorpe earlier this year he said that
this new LP from the band does not rely
quite as much on live instrumentation
and explores a lot more synthetic
electronic textures and I suppose in a
way present tense is wild beasts
electronic record however this album
wasn't really the shift in style or
sound or aesthetic that I thought it was
going to be based on the conversation
that I had it's not like this was the
kind of change that Liars made for
example from their LP sister world to
wish you which was a significant change
in the band sound and how they wrote
songs while beasts however even though
there is a bit of a Sonic change on this
LP they still rely on a lot of the same
slower smoother sexier grooves more
sensual Melodies and they bring their
usual vocal style along for the ride as
well on this LP2 and the inclusion of
more synthesizers on this new record of
theirs isn't really that overwhelming of
a change since the drum beats and the
vocals are really what kind of take
Reigns on these songs anyway which isn't
necessarily a bad thing since that is
exactly what has made wild beasts sound
so seductive over their past few albums
anyway for the most part the band's
strengths remain the same but I think
their weaknesses do as well the Dynamics
between the band's two lead singers are
still really impressive the songs on the
selfie overall are very enjoyable a lot
of the tunes here continue to set a kind
of sexy tone however I'm still pretty
lukewarm on how wild beasts approaches
sound and even though there are some
tracks here where it seems like wild
beast Stacks one synth sound on top of
another I'm not finding this record to
be nearly as colorful as the cover that
they've slapped on it and I think
they're really touching vocals and tunes
and occasionally very Bold lyrics do
kind of get hindered by the sounds that
wild beasts layer into these songs like
with the opening track the lead single
from this LP Wanderlust I think the
release still flat rough base
synthesizers that just sort of warble
away in the background on this song
don't really set that great of a tone
neither does the very numbing drumby in
one stiff synth phrase after another it
just makes the song's momentum feel
non-existent by the time the track is
halfway through again if it weren't for
the singing and the fact that the song
has a pretty epic ending I don't think I
would have dug the track at all I think
this stiffness pervades other tracks on
here like daughters and then there's the
closer on here which to me sounds sort
of like a Kate bushel-like 80s tinged
Art Pop ballad that could have ended a
movie and played while the credits
rolled despite really blunt lyrics on
this LP like don't confuse me for
someone who gives a I think there
are a lot of sounds on this record that
feel a little sterile occasionally I
just get the feeling that wild beasts
did not dig too far or manipulate too
far the synthesizer sounds the electron
Phonics that they actually went into
this record using it felt like the band
just went down another Avenue to execute
what they typically do as opposed to use
this opportunity to find a plethora of
entirely new sounds to build their songs
off of for someone who was hoping for
more of a significant change on this new
record of theirs it's a little
underwhelming but for somebody who loves
wild beasts sounding exactly the way
that they typically sound it could be a
good thing I guess at the end of the day
wild beasts is never going to be that
kind of sonically spelunking sort of
band and that doesn't mean this record
is a disappointment to me merely because
of that because again they do deliver
good songs like the song Mecca I love
the descending vocal Melody on this
track because away a serious highlight
on this record for me and I love the
stuttering guitar solo in the second
half of this track too there's the song
pregnant pause a really powerful piano
ballad delivered by Hayden Thorpe on
this track really beautiful singing
across the song and I love the way that
the instrumentation builds from the
beginning to the end of the track it
does show a significant amount of
progression from the start to the finish
and I love how the abrupt ending comes
in based off of the phrase in the hook
pregnant
uh oh we're just we're finishing we're
not what there's just silence you know
pregnant pause you know
then there's the track of simple and
beautiful truth which in my opinion
actually should have beat out Wanderlust
for the single off of this LP yeah for
sure it does not signify as bold a
change in the band's sound as Wanderlust
but I love the synthesizers in the
background of this track it seems like
they would have been more fit for a set
of stringed instruments to be playing
them but still I love the way that they
just lightly pump away
the falsetto on the hook that Hayden
delivers on this track is absolutely
sexy and this song I think has maybe the
most irresistible groove on the entire
album
simple and beautiful truth there's a
dog's life which is one of the slow
burners off of this LP and maybe the
only Tom fleming-led song that I really
loved mostly because of its huge
climactic ending one of the few moments
on this LP where I felt like wild beasts
really made use of the additional
Electronics on this LP and built up a
lush wall of sound to climax this track
a really powerful moment on this LP and
also something on this record that makes
me think how amazing it would be if wild
beasts Incorporated more epic spots in
their albums like this but what he had
to do wait for the next record and
listen to that that's what I'm gonna do
this record for me was a very good
listen there are some tracks that truly
do pale in comparison to others and I'm
not one over completely by the
incredibly slight change in Direction at
least what seems slight to me change in
direction that wild beasts made on this
LP still whatever shortcomings wild
beasts do have instrumentally I think
their songs and their singing continue
to be impressive I'm feeling a strong
six to a light seven on this thing
transition if you've given this record a
listen what did you think of it did you
love it did you hate it why what do you
think I should review next and that's
about it Anthony fantano music review
forever
